bestBHT.bht: After His discourses to the Jews, our Lord retired to Bethany beyond Jordan. Although a large portion of the sayings and doings of Jesus during this time are omitted, it is evident that He was accompanied by followers from Galilee or those with a favorable disposition towards Him. This marked His final departure from Galilee as He journeyed into Judea and Perea, where great multitudes sought Him out. Jesus faithfully taught the word of God to the people who gathered around Him, as was His custom wherever He went.

Henry Alford: Our Lord retired, after His discourses to the Jews in John x. and before the raising of Lazarus, to Bethany beyond Jordan."
In the strictest sense of the words He did come into the borders of Judæa and beyond Jordan."
Here a large portion of the sayings and doings of Jesus is omitted.
Philip Schaff: From thence. From Capernaum, the final departure from Galilee.
And beyond the Jordan (Perea). The common reading is ‘through the farther side of (beyond) the Jordan.’
Come together unto him again. As they had done on the previous visit (John 16 : 41 , 42 ), or as occurred in Galilee.
Archibald T. Robertson: A great deal has intervened between the events at the close of Mark 9 and those in the beginning of Mark 10."
Many of them are followers of Jesus from Galilee or at least kindly disposed towards him."
Jesus was teaching this moving caravan.
John Gill: And he arose from thence.... From Galilee, and particularly from Capernaum..."
And the people resorted unto him again; great multitudes followed him out of Galilee..."
And, as he was wont, he taught them again: it had been his custom before, and so it was wherever he went, to preach the word of God...

bhtAttempts.bht: After Jesus' discourses to the Jews in John, He retired to Bethany beyond Jordan. Although this passage omits much of what transpired between Mark 9 and 10, it is clear that Jesus was teaching a moving caravan of followers that included many from Galilee or at least those favorably disposed towards Him. This journey marked His final departure from Galilee and transition into Judea and Perea, where great multitudes sought Him out and He continued to faithfully preach the word of God.

After Jesus' teachings to the Jews, He withdrew to Bethany beyond Jordan. It is worth noting that a great deal has transpired between the events in Mark 9 and those in the beginning of Mark 10, yet Jesus was accompanied by a diverse group of followers, including many from Galilee. Jesus was seen teaching this moving caravan, which marked His final departure from Galilee and the beginning of His journey to Judea and Perea.

Our Lord retreated to Bethany beyond Jordan following His discourses to the Jews, while a lot of the sayings and doings of Jesus during this time are omitted. However, it is clear that He was joined by many followers from Galilee or those sympathetic to Him. This journey marked His final departure from Galilee as He transitioned into Judea and Perea, where great multitudes sought Him out. Throughout His journey, Jesus diligently continued to teach the word of God to the people who gathered around Him.

After His discourses to the Jews, our Lord retired to Bethany beyond Jordan. Although a large portion of the sayings and doings of Jesus during this time are omitted, it is evident that He was accompanied by followers from Galilee or those with a favorable disposition towards Him. This marked His final departure from Galilee as He journeyed into Judea and Perea, where great multitudes sought Him out. Jesus faithfully taught the word of God to the people who gathered around Him, as was His custom wherever He went.

After His teachings to the Jews, Jesus withdrew to Bethany beyond Jordan. While many events were omitted from the narrative, it is evident that He was accompanied by followers from Galilee or those favorably disposed towards Him. This marked His final departure from Galilee as He transitioned into Judea and Perea, where great multitudes sought Him out. Jesus faithfully taught the word of God to the people who gathered around Him, as was His customary practice wherever He went.
